 My content received 134,954 views! Glad they sparked conversations.

posts.name:
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
posts.content:
100 CONVERSATIONS. 0 CONVERSIONS. Been there?

Let's fix it: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Listen Actively:

‚Üí 46% of buyers rate active listening, as the top skill in sales.

‚Ü≥ Listening ‚Üí Discovering pain points.

‚Ü≥ Pain points ‚Üí Personalized solutions.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Personalize Solutions:

‚Üí 77% of B2B buyers won‚Äôt purchase without a tailored solution.

‚Ü≥ Personalised solutions ‚Üí Questions from prospects.

‚Ü≥ Questions ‚Üí Objections.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Handle Objections Strategically:

‚Üí Top sales reps ask clarifying questions, 54.3% of the time when facing objections.

Objections aren‚Äôt walls‚Äîthey‚Äôre opportunities.

By asking the right questions:

‚Ü≥ You shift focus from price ‚Üí value.

‚Ü≥ You help them arrive at the solution themselves.

‚Ü≥ You build trust while uncovering pain points.

For me, "Trust > Transactions". Always.

Follow to get smarter at "Mindset ‚Üí Money".

Because, you deserve to be in the "1% Club"! Ô∏è

PS: Are you able to add to the list? Share in the comments!

comments.commentText:
Sales isn‚Äôt about pushing. 

It‚Äôs about listening, personalizing, and handling objections like a pro.

Shift the focus: pain points ‚Üí solutions ‚Üí trust.

Trust > Transactions.
Great great points, asking the right questions and letting the client come to the cocnlusion himself is such an important key! Yash Kumar

Daniel Epstein That is genuinely an insightful answer. 

For me, it‚Äôs always about personalisation. Each human being is a different personality, with different objectives, values and pain points.

Knowing the prospect and their psychology really well, then, providing tailored solutions, has worked the best so far.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Active listening truly transforms conversations into meaningful connections. Lets keep building that trust! üí°ü§ù #SalesExcellence

posts.name:
Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
posts.content:
‚ÄòYour main marketing channel is founder brand.‚Äô he smirked. We had built a $5M ARR business with nothing but journey-led marketing.

They had 20 outbound SDRs and a traditional sales playbook.

I had a founder newsletter (and, at the time a blog) and a simple rule about trust.

Guess which company had shorter sales cycles?

The conversation happened a few years back and I still remember it like yesterday. It went like this:

Them: "What's your outbound strategy?"

Me: "We don't have one. We're inbound-led."

Them: "That's impossible. How do you predict revenue?"

I had to laugh. Because here's what I didn't tell them:

It's amazing how sales velocity emerges when you're building genuine relationships and trust over time directly w/ your ICP (and respond to inbound signals instead of chasing with cold outreach).

Some real numbers from our "unscalable" approach vs traditional SDR math:

- 70% faster sales cycles
- 3x pipeline per rep
- 140K engaged email list subscribers
- Team of 5 (yes, total)

But these metrics barely came up. Instead, I got the usual:

"You need more SDRs"
"Content doesn't scale"
"What about predictable revenue?"

Here's what I've learned after 12 years of journey-led growth:

The best sales decisions come from having skin in the game.

When it's your reputation on the line, you develop an instinct for value that no sales script can replicate.

I'm proud that every deal we've closed started from trust built organically, not cold calls. Every relationship we've built was because the our content pulled our ICP in, not because we pushed our way to them.

The irony? By staying journey-led and content-driven, we have more predictable growth than many traditional sales orgs.

No meetings about activity metrics.

No pressure to hit call quotas.

Just the simple mandate to build something customers want to engage with.

To my fellow journey-led founders: Next time someone questions your "scalability", remember‚Äîthere's nothing unscalable about building a business that runs on trust.

It's not about how many calls you make.

It's about how much value you create for your customers.

And sometimes, the best sales strategy is simply building trust over time by providing the value your ICP is actually looking for, not constantly selling people into oblivion.

comments.commentText: I concur with this approach. My company is purely inbound led and always has been. I‚Äôm not a fan of a hard sell or pushing product on people. For a long time we never really had marketing and even now it‚Äôs still in infant form. I always wanted to get the product right and also ensure we had a good process around customer service, onboarding etc. It‚Äôs hard as grow to get people into this mindset of growth but our trials are still boyant despite moving across 3 diff e-commerce platforms. I‚Äôm not saying it‚Äôs only strategy but being an inbound lead PLG word of mouth company gives you a fantastic backbone to be able to build on.

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely love this perspective! Trust and genuine relationships drive lasting success. Heres to valuing quality over quantity! üåü #JourneyLedGrowth

posts.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
posts.content:
Welcome to the New Social Saturday. 


Since doing this a few months ago worked so well,

I decided to do it again.

I will introduce you to anyone you want to meet in my network

no questions asked.

You dont have to
-> tell me why you want to meet them
-> do anything for me in return, ever

The great thing about this platform is the people you meet and the relationships you forge.

The greatest capital in the world is relationship capital.

"The currency of real networking is not greed but generosity."
- Keith Ferrazzi

Yours truthfully,
